thread.title: Foothill V-Ball roundup: Valencia volleyball stays a step ahead
thread.title_full: Foothill V-Ball roundup: Valencia volleyball stays a step ahead

author: Lorrie Reyes
title: Foothill V-Ball roundup: Valencia volleyball stays a step ahead
text:
Foothill V-Ball roundup: Valencia volleyball stays a step ahead Valencia’s strong run through league continues; Hart knocks off Canyon Posted: October 20, 2015 10:03 p.m. Updated: October 20, 2015 10:03 p.m. Valencia’s Rachel Perez (25) taps a shot over the net against West Ranch defenders Jordan Hilst (10) and Cassidy Peters (7) at West Ranch on Tuesday. Signal photo by Dan Watson. A A A 
The Valencia girls volleyball team is soaring above the rest of the Foothill League. 
The Vikings stayed unbeaten in league play Tuesday night, sweeping West Ranch in straight games (25-16, 25-13, 25-14) at West Ranch High. 
Even after graduating six players from last year’s CIF-Southern Section playoff team, Valencia (15-7 overall, 6-0 in Foothill) has only dropped one game in its six league matches so far. 
“I am really hoping we go undefeated the whole season because my sophomore and junior year on varsity we lost at least one (match),” said Valencia opposite Emily Burns. “We’ve never been undefeated. So I’m really hoping we do it this year because that’s important for me, and it’ll lead (us) into CIF with the momentum.” 
But the Vikings already have momentum. 
Since outside hitter Lauren Russ and middle blocker Bri Coleman have been inserted into the Valencia lineup, the Vikings have been even stronger than the first half of the conference season. 
“The last time we played Valencia we weren’t proud of our performance but today we are,” said West Ranch head coach Brandon Pank. “It’s tough to see, but we played way better volleyball against a way better Valencia team. Last time they didn’t have Lauren Russ, they didn’t have Bri Coleman, who are two clear starters and some of the best volleyball players in this valley.” 
Russ, who is a sophomore and was briefly out at the beginning of conference due to a rolled ankle, had a game-high 13 kills and 12 digs in Valencia’s win over West Ranch. 
Coleman, who transferred from Saugus and had to sit out for 30 days due to a mandatory CIF rule, added four kills and two blocks on the night. 
Burns tallied 12 kills, while Kelsey Knudsen added nine kills. Rachel Perez led the Vikings in passing with 37 assists and notched two aces, 
But Valencia hasn’t just been successful on offense, Tuesday night its defense was key. 
Demi Dawson led the Vikings with 15 digs, while Russ and Knudsen added 12 digs on the night. Burns had another five digs. 
“I thought we did a really nice job on defense,” said Valencia head coach Ray Sanchez. “We did really great things all around, except for serving. It was a well-played match once we served the ball in.” 
The Vikings did have 14 service errors on the night. 
The service errors helped the Wildcats, who served, passed and blocked the ball well. But the West Ranch attack couldn’t get enough strikes to get through the tough Valencia defense. 
Leading the Wildcats were Annika Bergstrom and Janessa Chase with three kills each. Chase had eight digs. 
Jordan Hilst and Kaitlin Schultz both had three blocks on the night, and Katie Jacobs and Tasha Skabelund each tallied two blocks against the strong Valencia strikers. 
West Ranch moves to 3-3 in league and 7-9-1 overall. The Wildcats next face Hart Thursday night at Hart High. 
Hart 3, Canyon 0 
The Indians improved to 5-1 in league play and 9-4 overall after sweeping the Cowboys 3-0 by game scores of 25-11, 25-14, 25-13 on Tuesday night. Lexi Chabiniak led Hart on the attack with nine kills. The Indians’ Brooke Boron added eight kills, while Natasha Stewart notched five kills. Ashley Aponik tallied 26 assists on the night for Hart.
